From among the large number of prominent American
universities and colleges entered in the Freedoms Foundation's
nationwide competition. The Distinguished Awards Jury, headed
by Dr. M. E. Sadler, president of Texas Christian University,
selected Harding College tq receive the top award for a campus
program strengthening and safeguarding the structure of Ameri¬
can Freedom. Dr. Benson was called to Valley Forge, Pennsyl¬
vania, on Washington's Birthday to personally receive the coveted
Thomas Jefferson Award, highest recognition in America for
building citizenship and citizen leaders dedicated to the basic
principles and institutions of freedom. Harding College also
was awarded the Distinguished Service plaque for having been
honored eight consecutive years by Freedoms Foundation', and
Dr. Benson personally received the George Washington Honor
Medal for his address: A Job for American Industry and Edu¬
cation. Harding's competition for the Jefferson Award included:
United States Military Academy, University of Southern Cali¬
fornia, University of California at Los Angeles, University of
Texas, Georgetown University, The Citadel, University of San
Francisco, Tufts University, and University of Wyoming, and
about 40 other colleges. Said Dr. Kenneth D. Wells, president
of Freedoms Foundation: "Our 1958 Distinguished Awards Jury
has said that the program in American citizenship education at
Harding College is one of the greatest things being done in
America."

Hundreds of high school students submitted entries.
In order to assure a saturation use of the “American Adventure” series,
the First Citizens Bank and Trust Company organized a speakers’ bureau
to visit schools and assist principals and teachers where necessary in the use
of the films; radio and television spot announcements were carried three
times daily, and the films were made available to schools and Parent-Teacher
Associations and civic clubs for local showings.
The essays were judged by three distinguished North Carolinians:
W. W. Taylor, Jr., president of the North Carolina Bar Association; Ben R.
Roberts, State Commissioner of Banks; and
State Treasurer Edwin Gill. The contest
ended just before schools recessed for the
summer vacations. Winners were to be
announced shortly.

being published as a guide to “saturation”
use of the film series throughout the nation.

Freedom Forums held in Oklahoma City in January and on the Harding Campus
at Searcy in April more nearly approached the ideal—in programming and in the make-up
of the conferee bodies—than any since the Forums were inaugurated ten years ago.
So that our patrons and friends may better appreciate the widespread reach and the effec¬
tiveness of these Forums, we are listing on the back cover the conferees and principals who
participated in Forum XIX on the Harding Campus.
The Oklahoma City Forum was attended by 115 business and industrial execu¬
tives, including several presidents, vice-presidents and union labor people; clergymen,
civic club officers, American Farm Bureau regional officials, and educators from a region
embracing Texas, Kansas and Oklahoma. The conferees responded enthusiastically to a
busy three-day program featuring presentations by Dave Crawford Houston, economic
education specialist with Kennecott Copper Corporation; Herbert Philbrick, famed FBI
counterspy; Dr. Sylvester Petro, New York University law professor and economist;
Robb M. Winsborough, vice-president of Middle West Service Company; Dr. Benson
who keynoted and closed the Forum; and Dr. Clifton L. Ganus and Glenn Green,
dramatizing the comparative economics in America and the European Welfare States.

SELLING THE AMERICAN SYSTEM
TO HIGH SCHOOL AND COLLEGE YOUTH
Forty-six educators participated in this Forum. Two of the immediate results in the educa¬
tional field were the establishment of American citizenship courses in the public schools
of Tulsa and at Muskogee. Officials of these school systems attended the Forum and a
few weeks later called upon Dr. Benson to address the faculties and student bodies to
inaugurate new citizenship courses built with the Forum materials.
Central Christian College co-sponsored the Forum with the National Program.
By popular demand of the 115 conferees and the distinguished industrial leaders on the
Oklahoma Advisory Committee this Oklahoma City Forum is to become an annual affair.
At the April Forum in Searcy we were hosts to 107 people from 25 states.
State Departments of Education in Virginia and Washington, school systems from 15
states and three colleges and universities were represented in the conferee body. The
Forum concentrated its attention on the problem of achieving widespread dissemination
of the comparative facts of political and economic systems. Eight members of the Forum
Advisory Committee—personnel and communications executives from General Motors,
General Electric, Folger’s Coffee, Pepsi-Cola Bottlers, Hinde & Dauch, Monsanto Chemi¬
cal, the Indianapolis Chamber of Commerce, and the Washington State Department of
Public Instruction—personally assisted the NEP staff with the operation of the Forum.
Forum-end evaluations and specific back-home results reported were especially en¬
couraging to Dr. Benson and gave assurance that this Forum was one of the most suc¬
cessful in the series begun 10 years ago. Many of the 26 educators in attendance spoke up
at the final session to pledge themselves to the immediate development of classroom
courses designed to bring about a keen appreciation of our private enterprise economic
system and our Republican form of Government. A feature of Forum XIX was the
attendance of 31 retired U. S. Army Colonels and Generals, residents and most of them
employed in Arkansas Educational Work. They were special conferee guests of the NEP.
